subject: Re: [junit] Re: TestUtil: By Example
msgSnippet: ... In our current architecture - we say that a method should either accept Null, an EmptyString, etc. as a valid input or it should throw an ArgumentException
messageBody:
> It's sometimes okay for methods to receive null arguments. You would need a
> way to differentiate methods that need a non-null parameter (@NonNull) but
> even so, the method is probably going to throw an NPE, so where is the added
> value?

In our current architecture - we say that a method should either
accept Null, an EmptyString, etc. as a valid input or it should throw
an ArgumentException (AE). So in our world view a NPE indicates a
coding error inside the API. I like the distinction an AE says that
the API is not being used correctly whereas a NPE says the API is
broken.

Ron Jefferies thinks this approach is dead wrong and that methods
should just do the right thing with Null's etc. I just don't see what
the right thing is most of these cases.

So my suggestion was pass in Null, emptyString, etc. to methods (not
restricted to tests). If they either threw an AE or didn't throw
anything then they would be deemed to have passed. It would indicate
that the developer had considered what to do with Null's et al.

The hard part is dealing with methods that have multiple parameters.
For any method that has more than one object as a parameter, you have
to be able to create an instance of those objects - so that you're
tests only test one parameter at a time.

> Don't get me wrong, the idea is interesting, I'm just trying to come up with
> the example of a bug that would be faster to find using this method...

You would find cases where the developer hadn't consider how to handle
these edge cases.

Mark
